message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The purple spots and positive Gram stain for gram-negative diplococci suggest the patient has meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is the preferred prophylactic treatment for close contacts of patients with meningococcal disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the gram-negative diplococci suggest that the patient has meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is the preferred prophylactic antibiotic for close contacts of patients with meningococcal disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, along with the gram-negative diplococci seen on the lumbar puncture, suggest meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is the recommended prophylactic treatment for close contacts of someone with meningococcal disease. Penicillin G and cephalexin are not effective against meningococcal infection, and doxycycline is not commonly used in prophylaxis for meningococcal disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the purple spots and gram-negative diplococci, suggest the patient has meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is commonly used as prophylaxis for close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis, so it is the best option for preventing infection in the patient's brother at this time. Penicillin G is the first-line treatment for meningococcal meningitis, but it is not indicated for prophylaxis. Cephalexin and doxycycline are not effective against meningococcal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the gram-negative diplococci suggest meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin can prevent the spread of the infection to individuals who have been in close contact with the patient, such as his brother. Penicillin G is used to treat the infection, while cephalexin and doxycycline are not effective against meningococcal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of purple spots and the gram-negative diplococci suggest a diagnosis of meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is recommended for prophylaxis in close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis. Penicillin G is used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis but not for prophylaxis. Cephalexin and doxycycline are not effective for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gram-negative diplococci in the cerebrospinal fluid suggest meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is used for chemoprophylaxis of household contacts of patients with meningococcal disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The purple spots and gram-negative diplococci in the cerebrospinal fluid suggest that the patient has meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis to prevent secondary infection. Penicillin G is used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis but not for prevention of secondary infection. Cephalexin and doxycycline are not appropriate choices for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The purple spots and the gram-negative diplococci suggest that the patient has meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is used for prophylaxis for close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis. Penicillin G is used for treatment, but not for prevention, of meningococcal meningitis. Cephalexin and doxycycline are not effective against this type of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests the patient has meningococcal meningitis, which is caused by Neisseria meningitidis. Rifampin is effective in eliminating nasopharyngeal carriage of Neisseria meningitidis in close contacts of patients with invasive meningococcal disease, and therefore is the drug of choice for prophylaxis. Penicillin G and cephalexin are not effective against Neisseria meningitidis, and doxycycline is not recommended for prophylaxis in children.
